lessons.title: What is a Computer Keyboard?
lessons.content:
A computer keyboard is an input device used to type letters, numbers, and symbols into a computer. It works like the keyboard on your phone or a typewriter, but it has many more keys and special functions.

What it does:
‚Ä¢ Lets you write messages, type schoolwork, and give commands to the computer.
‚Ä¢ Helps you use shortcuts to work faster.

How it looks:
Keyboards usually have several sections: letters, numbers, function keys, navigation keys, and a numeric keypad. Most have small bumps on the F and J keys to help you find the home row without looking.

lessons.title: Layout of the Keyboard
lessons.content:
The keyboard layout is how keys are arranged on the keyboard. The most common layout is called QWERTY because the first six letters in the top row are Q W E R T Y.

Main areas:
‚Ä¢ Typing area: letters and punctuation.
‚Ä¢ Number row: numbers and symbols above the letters.
‚Ä¢ Function keys: F1‚ÄìF12 across the top.
‚Ä¢ Navigation keys: arrows, Home, End, Page Up, Page Down.
‚Ä¢ Numeric keypad: on the right for fast number entry.

Other layouts: AZERTY (used in France), DVORAK (designed to reduce finger movement), and QWERTZ (Central Europe). Different countries and languages choose layouts that suit their needs.

lessons.title: Categories of Keys
lessons.content:
Keys on the keyboard are grouped by what they do. Knowing the groups helps you learn faster.

Main categories:
‚Ä¢ Alphabet (A‚ÄìZ): Used to type words.
‚Ä¢ Number keys (0‚Äì9): Above letters and on the numeric keypad.
‚Ä¢ Function keys (F1‚ÄìF12): Special tasks depending on the program.
‚Ä¢ Control keys: Ctrl, Alt, Esc ‚Äî used with other keys for shortcuts.
‚Ä¢ Navigation keys: Arrow keys, Home, End, Page Up, Page Down.
‚Ä¢ Numeric keypad: Quick number entry for calculations.
‚Ä¢ Special keys: Enter, Shift, Spacebar, Backspace, Tab.

Knowing categories makes typing and using shortcuts easier.

lessons.title: How to Use the Keyboard for Typing
lessons.content:
Typing well helps you finish schoolwork faster and write neatly on a computer.

Good posture:
‚Ä¢ Sit up straight, feet flat on the floor.
‚Ä¢ Keep the screen at eye level and your wrists slightly raised.

Home row:
‚Ä¢ Place your left fingers on A, S, D, F and your right fingers on J, K, L, ;. Thumbs rest on the spacebar. The bumps on F and J help you find the position without looking.

Finger use:
‚Ä¢ Each finger is responsible for certain keys ‚Äî don‚Äôt use just one finger for everything.

Practice tips:
‚Ä¢ Start slowly, focus on accuracy, then build speed.
‚Ä¢ Try typing games and short daily lessons.

lessons.title: Function Keys (F1‚ÄìF12)
lessons.content:
The Function Keys are the special keys at the top of the keyboard, labeled from F1 to F12. Each key has its own job or command that helps you work faster on the computer. Their functions can change depending on the program you are using.


üñ±Ô∏è Here‚Äôs What Each Function Key Does:

  • F1 ‚Äì Opens the Help window in most programs.
  • F2 ‚Äì Rename a selected file or folder.
  • F3 ‚Äì Opens search in many programs and browsers.
  • F4 ‚Äì Alt + F4 closes the active window or program.
  • F5 ‚Äì Refresh or reload a webpage or document.
  • F6 ‚Äì Moves cursor to the browser address bar (in many browsers).
  • F7 ‚Äì Starts spelling and grammar checks in some programs like Word.
  • F8 ‚Äì Used for accessing Safe Mode on startup on some computers (advanced).
  • F9 ‚Äì Refreshes or runs send/receive in some email programs and updates spreadsheets.
  • F10 ‚Äì Activates the program menu bar. Shift + F10 acts like a right-click menu.
  • F11 ‚Äì Toggles full-screen mode in web browsers.
  • F12 ‚Äì Often opens Save As or developer tools in browsers.

Tip: On laptops you may need to hold the Fn key to use F1‚ÄìF12. Function keys can also be combined with Ctrl, Alt, or Shift for extra shortcuts.

lessons.title: Home and End Keys
lessons.content:
The Home and End keys help you move quickly through text and pages.

What they do:
‚Ä¢ Home ‚Äì Moves the cursor to the start of the current line.
‚Ä¢ End ‚Äì Moves the cursor to the end of the current line.

When used with Ctrl:
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + Home ‚Äì Jump to the beginning of the document or page.
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + End ‚Äì Jump to the end of the document or page.

These keys save time when you edit long documents.

lessons.title: Arrow Keys
lessons.content:
The Arrow Keys let you move the cursor or selection without using the mouse.

How they work:
‚Ä¢ Up (‚Üë) ‚Äì move up
‚Ä¢ Down (‚Üì) ‚Äì move down
‚Ä¢ Left (‚Üê) ‚Äì move left
‚Ä¢ Right (‚Üí) ‚Äì move right

Common uses:
‚Ä¢ Move through text, navigate menus, move a character in games, or move between spreadsheet cells.

Tip: Hold Shift + arrow keys to select text or items.

lessons.title: Control Keys (Ctrl)
lessons.content:
The Ctrl key is used with other keys to perform quick commands called shortcuts.

Useful Ctrl shortcuts:
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + A ‚Äì Select all
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + C ‚Äì Copy selected text or files
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + V ‚Äì Paste copied items
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + X ‚Äì Cut (remove and copy)
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + Z ‚Äì Undo last action
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + Y ‚Äì Redo
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + S ‚Äì Save
‚Ä¢ Ctrl + P ‚Äì Print

Using Ctrl shortcuts makes tasks faster and reduces mouse clicks.

lessons.title: Shift Key
lessons.content:
The Shift key changes what other keys do. You usually have two Shift keys on the keyboard.

Common uses:
‚Ä¢ Hold Shift + letter to type a capital letter (Shift + a = A).
‚Ä¢ Hold Shift + number keys to type the top symbol (Shift + 1 = !, Shift + 2 = @).
‚Ä¢ Use Shift + Arrow to select text without using the mouse.

Shift is simple but very useful for typing capitals and symbols.

lessons.title: Number Keys
lessons.content:
Number keys are the keys labeled 0‚Äì9 above the letter row. They let you type numbers in documents, forms, and calculators.

Quick tips:
‚Ä¢ Use the row above letters for small numbers in text.
‚Ä¢ Use the numeric keypad on the right for fast number entry (if your keyboard has one).
‚Ä¢ Hold Shift with number keys for symbols: Shift + 1 = !, Shift + 2 = @, and so on.

lessons.title: Numeric and Symbol Keys
lessons.content:
This topic covers the numeric keypad and symbol keys used for math and special characters.

Numeric keypad:
‚Ä¢ Located on the right side of many keyboards.
‚Ä¢ Works like a calculator for quick entry of numbers and math signs (+, -, *, /).
‚Ä¢ Turn on Num Lock to use it as numbers.

Symbol keys:
‚Ä¢ Symbols like ! @ # $ % ^ & * are typed with Shift + the number or symbol key.
‚Ä¢ Use symbols for passwords, email addresses, and math.

lessons.title: Home Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Home Row is the middle row of letters where your fingers rest while typing.

Finger positions:
‚Ä¢ Left hand: A S D F
‚Ä¢ Right hand: J K L ;

Your thumbs rest on the spacebar. The little bumps on F and J help you find the home row without looking at the keyboard.

Practicing the home row helps you type faster and without looking at the keys.

lessons.title: Top Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Top Row contains the letters Q W E R T Y U I O P and sits above the home row.

These keys are used in many common words (like 'type', 'quick', 'you'), so learning them improves typing speed. Move your fingers up from the home row to reach these keys and return to home row after pressing them.

lessons.title: Bottom Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Bottom Row sits below the home row and includes Z X C V B N M and punctuation keys like comma and period.

Other important keys near the bottom row include Spacebar, Ctrl, Alt, and the Windows key. Practice reaching these keys smoothly from the home row.

lessons.title: Punctuation Keys
lessons.content:
Punctuation marks make writing clear. The keyboard provides keys for all the punctuation you need.

Common punctuation:
‚Ä¢ Period (.) ‚Äì ends a sentence.
‚Ä¢ Comma (,) ‚Äì small pause in a sentence.
‚Ä¢ Question mark (?) ‚Äì asks a question.
‚Ä¢ Exclamation (!) ‚Äì shows excitement.
‚Ä¢ Colon (:) and semicolon (;) ‚Äì link ideas.
‚Ä¢ Quotation marks ‚Äì show speech.

Use punctuation correctly to make your writing easy to read.

lessons.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
lessons.content:
Keyboard shortcuts are special key combinations that help you perform tasks quickly without using the mouse. They save time and make your work faster and easier.

What Are Keyboard Shortcuts?
Keyboard shortcuts use one or more keys pressed together to tell the computer to do something. For example, instead of moving your mouse to click 'Copy', you can press Ctrl + C.

Common Keyboard Shortcuts:
‚úÖ Ctrl + C ‚Äì Copy selected text or files
‚úÖ Ctrl + V ‚Äì Paste what you copied
‚úÖ Ctrl + X ‚Äì Cut (remove and copy) selected text
‚úÖ Ctrl + S ‚Äì Save your document
‚úÖ Ctrl + Z ‚Äì Undo your last action
‚úÖ Ctrl + A ‚Äì Select all
‚úÖ Ctrl + P ‚Äì Print
‚úÖ Alt + Tab ‚Äì Switch between open windows
‚úÖ Ctrl + Alt + Delete ‚Äì Open Task Manager (to close or restart apps)

Windows Shortcuts:
ü™ü Windows + E ‚Äì Open File Explorer
ü™ü Windows + D ‚Äì Show or hide the desktop
ü™ü Windows + L ‚Äì Lock your computer
ü™ü Windows + R ‚Äì Open the Run box
ü™ü Windows + I ‚Äì Open Settings
ü™ü Windows + Shift + S ‚Äì Take a screenshot (snip tool)

Typing Special Characters:
‚ú® Use the Alt key with numbers to type symbols (on the numeric keypad):
‚û° Alt + 0169 ‚Üí ¬©
‚û° Alt + 0174 ‚Üí ¬Æ
‚û° Alt + 0153 ‚Üí ‚Ñ¢
‚û° Alt + 3 ‚Üí ‚ô•

Function Keys (F1 ‚Äì F12):
üîπ F1 ‚Äì Help
üîπ F2 ‚Äì Rename a file or folder
üîπ F5 ‚Äì Refresh a page
üîπ F11 ‚Äì Full screen mode

Practice Tip:
Learn one new shortcut each day. Keep sticky notes near the keyboard until you memorize them!

lessons.title: What is a Computer Mouse?
lessons.content:
A computer mouse is an input device that allows you to point, click, and move objects on your computer screen. It helps you interact with programs without typing commands.

Parts of a mouse:
‚Ä¢ Left button ‚Äì select items and click.
‚Ä¢ Right button ‚Äì open menus.
‚Ä¢ Scroll wheel ‚Äì scroll through pages.
‚Ä¢ Body ‚Äì fits your hand comfortably.

lessons.title: Types of Computer Mouse
lessons.content:
There are different types of mice you can use.

Common types:
‚Ä¢ Wired Mouse ‚Äì connected with a cable.
‚Ä¢ Wireless Mouse ‚Äì uses Bluetooth or a USB receiver.
‚Ä¢ Optical Mouse ‚Äì uses light to detect movement.
‚Ä¢ Trackball Mouse ‚Äì move the cursor by rotating a ball.
‚Ä¢ Gaming Mouse ‚Äì extra buttons for games.

Each type works the same way but may feel different in your hand.

lessons.title: Mouse Buttons and Their Uses
lessons.content:
A standard mouse usually has two or three buttons.

Left button: Click to select or open files.
Right button: Click to see a menu with options.
Middle button / scroll wheel: Scroll pages, sometimes click to open links in a new tab.

Practice using each button for different tasks to become faster on the computer.

lessons.title: Mouse Actions
lessons.content:
Using a mouse involves different actions:

Click: Press and release the left button to select.
Double-click: Quickly click twice to open files or programs.
Right-click: Press the right button to show a menu.
Scroll: Use the wheel to move up and down pages.
Drag and drop: Hold the left button while moving an item.

Learning these actions helps you navigate the computer easily.

lessons.title: Drag and Drop
lessons.content:
Drag and drop lets you move files or objects on your screen.

How to do it:
1. Place the pointer over the item.
2. Press and hold the left mouse button.
3. Move the item to a new location.
4. Release the button.

This action is useful for organizing files, copying items, or creating folders.

lessons.title: Scrolling with the Mouse
lessons.content:
Scrolling lets you move through long pages without using the keyboard.

How to scroll:
‚Ä¢ Use the scroll wheel up or down.
‚Ä¢ Click and drag the scrollbar on the side of the screen.

Scrolling is faster than pressing arrow keys, especially for reading documents or browsing websites.

lessons.title: Clicking Basics
lessons.content:
Clicking is the main way to interact with your computer.

Types of clicks:
‚Ä¢ Single click: Select an item.
‚Ä¢ Double click: Open files or folders.
‚Ä¢ Right click: Open context menus.
‚Ä¢ Click and hold: Drag an object.

Practice clicking accurately to avoid mistakes while working.

lessons.title: Clicking and Dragging
lessons.content:
Clicking and dragging is used to move files or select multiple items.

Steps:
1. Click and hold the left button on an object.
2. Move the mouse to the desired location.
3. Release the button.

It‚Äôs important for organizing files or selecting large blocks of text.

lessons.title: High-Speed Precision Tasks
lessons.content:
Some tasks need precise mouse movements, like drawing, gaming, or graphic design.

Tips for precision:
‚Ä¢ Move the mouse slowly for accuracy.
‚Ä¢ Adjust the mouse sensitivity in settings.
‚Ä¢ Use a mouse pad for smooth movement.
‚Ä¢ Keep your hand relaxed to reduce fatigue.

lessons.title: Mouse Practice Activities
lessons.content:
Practice helps you become a fast and accurate mouse user.

Activities:
‚Ä¢ Open and close programs using clicks.
‚Ä¢ Drag and drop files into folders.
‚Ä¢ Scroll through documents and websites.
‚Ä¢ Play beginner mouse games online to improve speed and accuracy.

Regular practice builds confidence and skill.

lessons.title: What is a Computer?
lessons.content:
A computer is an electronic device that processes data and performs tasks according to instructions. It can store, retrieve, and display information.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Accepts input from devices like keyboard and mouse.
‚Ä¢ Processes information using the CPU.
‚Ä¢ Produces output on a monitor, printer, or speakers.
‚Ä¢ Stores information in memory or storage devices.

Examples: Desktop computers, laptops, tablets, and smartphones.

lessons.title: Parts of a Computer
lessons.content:
A computer has different parts that work together to perform tasks.

Main parts:
‚Ä¢ CPU (Central Processing Unit): The brain of the computer that processes data.
‚Ä¢ Monitor: Displays information.
‚Ä¢ Keyboard: Input device for typing.
‚Ä¢ Mouse: Input device for pointing and clicking.
‚Ä¢ Printer: Outputs documents on paper.
‚Ä¢ Storage: Hard drives, SSDs, or USB drives store information.
‚Ä¢ RAM (Memory): Temporarily holds data for running programs.

Understanding each part helps you use the computer effectively.

lessons.title: Uses of a Computer
lessons.content:
Computers are used in many areas of life and learning.

Common uses:
‚Ä¢ Education: Learn, type assignments, access e-books.
‚Ä¢ Communication: Send emails, messages, video calls.
‚Ä¢ Entertainment: Play games, watch videos, listen to music.
‚Ä¢ Business: Manage accounts, create reports, handle inventory.
‚Ä¢ Research: Find information online quickly.

Knowing uses helps you use a computer for the right tasks.

lessons.title: Safe Use of Computers
lessons.content:
Using a computer safely protects your body and information.

Physical safety:
‚Ä¢ Sit properly with feet flat and back straight.
‚Ä¢ Keep the screen at eye level.
‚Ä¢ Take breaks to rest eyes and hands.

Digital safety:
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt share passwords with anyone.
‚Ä¢ Avoid suspicious websites and downloads.
‚Ä¢ Log out from accounts on shared computers.

Safe use prevents accidents, fatigue, and cyber threats.

lessons.title: Introduction to Coding
lessons.content:
Coding is writing instructions for a computer to follow.

Why learn coding:
‚Ä¢ Makes computers do tasks automatically.
‚Ä¢ Helps you create games, animations, and apps.
‚Ä¢ Develops logical thinking and problem-solving skills.

Basic idea: Computers follow instructions line by line. Coding languages tell the computer what to do in a way it understands.

lessons.title: Scratch and Block Coding
lessons.content:
Scratch is a block-based coding platform for beginners. Instead of typing code, you drag blocks that represent commands.

How it works:
‚Ä¢ Sprites: Characters or objects in the program.
‚Ä¢ Blocks: Commands like move, turn, speak, or change color.
‚Ä¢ Stage: The area where sprites act.

By snapping blocks together, you can create animations, games, and interactive stories.

lessons.title: Algorithms for Kids
lessons.content:
An algorithm is a set of steps to solve a problem or complete a task.

Examples:
‚Ä¢ How to brush your teeth:
1. Pick up toothbrush.
2. Apply toothpaste.
3. Brush all teeth.
4. Rinse mouth.

‚Ä¢ How to make a sandwich:
1. Take bread.
2. Add filling.
3. Close bread.
4. Eat.

Algorithms in coding tell the computer exactly what steps to follow. Writing them clearly is very important.

lessons.title: Introduction to the Internet
lessons.content:
The Internet is a network of computers all over the world connected to share information.

Uses:
‚Ä¢ Send and receive emails.
‚Ä¢ Search for information online.
‚Ä¢ Watch videos and listen to music.
‚Ä¢ Play online games and communicate with friends.

Tips: Always use the Internet responsibly and safely.

lessons.title: Working with Files
lessons.content:
Files are digital documents, images, videos, or programs stored on a computer.

Common tasks:
‚Ä¢ Create: Make a new document or folder.
‚Ä¢ Save: Keep your work safe.
‚Ä¢ Open: View a file.
‚Ä¢ Rename: Give it a new name.
‚Ä¢ Delete: Remove files you no longer need.

Understanding files helps you organize and manage information efficiently.

lessons.title: Using the Internet
lessons.content:
Using the Internet safely and efficiently is an essential ICT skill.

Steps:
‚Ä¢ Open a browser like Chrome or Firefox.
‚Ä¢ Type the website address or search in the search engine.
‚Ä¢ Click links to view information.
‚Ä¢ Download or save content carefully.
‚Ä¢ Keep personal information private.

Practicing these steps makes learning online fun and secure.

lessons.title: What is an Operating System?
lessons.content:
An Operating System (OS) is software that manages all the hardware and software on a computer. It acts as a bridge between the user and the computer hardware.

Main roles:
‚Ä¢ Controls how the computer's hardware works.
‚Ä¢ Manages memory, files, and applications.
‚Ä¢ Provides a user interface so you can interact with the computer.

Examples: Windows, macOS, Linux, Android, iOS.

lessons.title: Types of Operating Systems (Windows, Mac, Linux)
lessons.content:
There are different types of operating systems for different devices and needs.

Main types:
‚Ä¢ Windows: Popular on desktops and laptops, user-friendly with many software options.
‚Ä¢ Mac (macOS): Used on Apple computers, known for design and reliability.
‚Ä¢ Linux: Open-source, customizable, used for servers and programming.
‚Ä¢ Mobile OS: Android and iOS for smartphones and tablets.

Choosing the right OS depends on the tasks you want to perform and the device you have.

lessons.title: How to Install an Operating System
lessons.content:
Installing an OS sets up your computer so it can run programs.

Steps:
1. Backup important files.
2. Insert installation media (USB/DVD) or download OS installer.
3. Boot the computer from the installation media.
4. Follow on-screen instructions to select language, region, and partition.
5. Complete installation and restart the computer.

Tip: Make sure your computer meets the OS requirements and you have a license if needed.

lessons.title: Functions of an Operating System
lessons.content:
The OS performs many important functions to keep the computer running smoothly.

Main functions:
‚Ä¢ File Management: Organizes files and folders on storage devices.
‚Ä¢ Memory Management: Allocates RAM to running programs efficiently.
‚Ä¢ Process Management: Controls the execution of applications and background tasks.
‚Ä¢ Device Management: Controls hardware like printers, keyboards, and monitors.
‚Ä¢ User Interface: Provides a graphical interface (GUI) or command-line interface (CLI) for user interaction.
‚Ä¢ Security: Protects against unauthorized access and malware.

Understanding these functions helps you use a computer safely and effectively.

lessons.title: What is Computer Software?
lessons.content:
Computer software is a set of instructions that tells a computer what to do. Unlike hardware, software is intangible ‚Äî you cannot touch it, but it makes the computer useful.

Types of software tasks:
‚Ä¢ Run applications like games, word processors, and web browsers.
‚Ä¢ Control computer hardware and manage files.
‚Ä¢ Connect to the internet and communicate with other devices.

Examples: Microsoft Word, Google Chrome, Antivirus programs.

lessons.title: Types of Software (System, Application, Utility)
lessons.content:
Software is grouped based on its function:

1. System Software: Helps the computer run and manages hardware (e.g., Operating System, drivers).
2. Application Software: Programs that perform tasks for users (e.g., Word, Excel, Games, Browsers).
3. Utility Software: Tools that maintain or protect the computer (e.g., Antivirus, Disk Cleanup, Backup tools).

Knowing the types of software helps you choose the right tool for a task.

lessons.title: Security Software (Antivirus, Firewalls)
lessons.content:
Security software protects your computer from viruses, hackers, and unwanted programs.

Common security software:
‚Ä¢ Antivirus: Detects and removes viruses and malware.
‚Ä¢ Firewall: Blocks unauthorized access to your computer from the internet.
‚Ä¢ Anti-spyware: Stops programs that try to steal your information.

Tips for safety:
‚Ä¢ Keep software updated.
‚Ä¢ Scan files regularly.
‚Ä¢ Avoid downloading files from unknown sources.

lessons.title: Productivity Software (Office, Browsers, Tools)
lessons.content:
Productivity software helps you perform tasks efficiently.

Examples:
‚Ä¢ Office suites: Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) for documents, spreadsheets, and presentations.
‚Ä¢ Web browsers: Google Chrome, Firefox, Edge to access the internet.
‚Ä¢ Tools: Calendar apps, note-taking apps, PDF readers.

Using productivity software improves your ability to complete tasks faster and with better quality.

lessons.title: Microsoft Word ‚Äì Introduction
lessons.content:
Microsoft Word is a word processing software used for typing, editing, and printing documents. It helps you create neat and well-arranged letters, stories, notes, and reports.

Uses of Microsoft Word:
‚Ä¢ Typing school notes or letters.
‚Ä¢ Editing and correcting spelling or grammar mistakes.
‚Ä¢ Inserting pictures, tables, and shapes.
‚Ä¢ Printing your work neatly.

Main Parts of the MS Word Window:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Title Bar ‚Äì shows the document name.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Ribbon ‚Äì contains tabs like Home, Insert, and Layout.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Workspace ‚Äì the blank area where you type.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Status Bar ‚Äì shows page number and word count.

Fun Tip: You can change the font, color, or size of your text to make it beautiful!

lessons.title: Editing and Formatting Text
lessons.content:
Editing means making corrections or changes to your work in Word. Formatting means making the text look more attractive.

Editing Tools:
‚Ä¢ Backspace/Delete: remove unwanted letters.
‚Ä¢ Undo (Ctrl + Z): cancel a mistake.
‚Ä¢ Redo (Ctrl + Y): restore an undone action.

Formatting Tools:
‚Ä¢ Bold (B): make text darker.
‚Ä¢ Italic (I): slant your text.
‚Ä¢ Underline (U): draw a line under your text.
‚Ä¢ Font Style and Size: change how your letters look.
‚Ä¢ Text Alignment: left, center, or right alignment.

Example:
Normal: Welcome to ICT Class
Formatted: Welcome to ICT Class

lessons.title: Microsoft Excel ‚Äì Introduction
lessons.content:
Microsoft Excel is a spreadsheet software used for working with numbers, calculations, and data. It helps to record, organize, and analyze information easily.

Main Features:
‚Ä¢ Each Excel file is called a Workbook.
‚Ä¢ Each workbook has Worksheets made up of rows and columns.
‚Ä¢ A cell is where a row and a column meet ‚Äì it‚Äôs where you type your data.

Common Uses of Excel:
‚Ä¢ Creating a timetable or class list.
‚Ä¢ Recording exam scores.
‚Ä¢ Adding and subtracting numbers.
‚Ä¢ Making simple charts or graphs.

Example:
| Name | Maths | English |
|-------|--------|----------|
| Ada | 85 | 90 |
| Tunde | 78 | 88 |

lessons.title: Using Formulas in Excel
lessons.content:
Formulas are used in Excel to perform calculations automatically.

Common Excel Formulas:
‚Ä¢ =A1+B1 ‚Üí Adds two numbers.
‚Ä¢ =A1-B1 ‚Üí Subtracts.
‚Ä¢ =A1*B1 ‚Üí Multiplies.
‚Ä¢ =A1/B1 ‚Üí Divides.
‚Ä¢ =SUM(A1:A5) ‚Üí Adds all numbers from cell A1 to A5.

Steps to Use a Formula:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Click on a cell where you want the answer.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Type the equal sign (=).
3Ô∏è‚É£ Type your formula (e.g., A1 + B1).
4Ô∏è‚É£ Press Enter.

Fun Tip: You can use formulas to calculate totals in your class score sheet automatically!

lessons.title: Microsoft PowerPoint ‚Äì Introduction
lessons.content:
Microsoft PowerPoint is a program used to create presentations made up of slides. It is useful for teaching, storytelling, and showing information in an interesting way.

Main Features:
‚Ä¢ Slides: each slide contains text, pictures, or charts.
‚Ä¢ Design Tab: lets you add colorful themes.
‚Ä¢ Transitions: control how slides change.
‚Ä¢ Animations: make text or pictures move.

Common Uses:
‚Ä¢ Classroom lessons.
‚Ä¢ School projects.
‚Ä¢ Business or church presentations.

Fun Tip: Add background music and pictures to make your slides more fun!

lessons.title: Creating and Presenting Slides
lessons.content:
To make a PowerPoint presentation, you combine several slides and then present them one by one.

Steps to Create a Slide Show:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Open PowerPoint and click New Slide.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Add a title and some text or pictures.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Use the Design Tab to choose colors and backgrounds.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Use Animations and Transitions to add movement.
5Ô∏è‚É£ Click Slide Show ‚Üí From Beginning to present.

Good Presentation Tips:
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt put too much text on one slide.
‚Ä¢ Use large, clear fonts.
‚Ä¢ Add relevant pictures.
‚Ä¢ Speak clearly and confidently when presenting.

lessons.title: Web Browsers and Search Engines
lessons.content:
A web browser is a program that lets you explore the internet. Examples include Google Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge.

Main Features:
‚Ä¢ Address Bar: Type a website address to visit it.
‚Ä¢ Tabs: Open multiple websites at the same time.
‚Ä¢ Bookmarks: Save your favorite websites.
‚Ä¢ History: Review the websites you visited.

A search engine helps you find information online. Examples include Google, Bing, and Yahoo.

Tips for Kids:
‚Ä¢ Always ask permission from parents or teachers before searching.
‚Ä¢ Type clear keywords to find information quickly.

lessons.title: Email Basics
lessons.content:
Email is a way to send messages using the internet.

Main Parts of an Email:
‚Ä¢ To: Who you are sending the email to.
‚Ä¢ Subject: A short description of your email.
‚Ä¢ Body: The main message.
‚Ä¢ Attachments: Files or pictures you want to share.

Tips for Kids:
‚Ä¢ Always write polite and clear messages.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt share passwords or personal information.
‚Ä¢ Check emails regularly for school updates.

lessons.title: Introduction to Social Media
lessons.content:
Social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok let people share messages, pictures, and videos.

Important Points for Kids:
‚Ä¢ Only use social media with adult supervision.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt share personal details like your address or phone number.
‚Ä¢ Think before you post; what you share online can be permanent.
‚Ä¢ Be kind and respectful when interacting with others.

Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Stay connected with friends and family.
‚Ä¢ Learn new skills and discover educational content.

lessons.title: Cybersecurity for Kids
lessons.content:
Cybersecurity means keeping your devices and information safe from hackers and viruses.

Tips to Stay Safe:
‚Ä¢ Use strong passwords that are hard to guess.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt click on unknown links or ads.
‚Ä¢ Keep software and antivirus programs up-to-date.
‚Ä¢ Ask an adult before downloading files from the internet.

Why it‚Äôs Important:
‚Ä¢ Protects your personal information.
‚Ä¢ Keeps your computer free from harmful programs.

lessons.title: Rules for Safe Internet Use
lessons.content:
Safe internet use is important to avoid dangers online.

Basic Rules:
‚Ä¢ Never share personal information (address, phone, school) online.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt talk to strangers on the internet.
‚Ä¢ Ask permission from a parent or teacher before visiting new websites.
‚Ä¢ Be respectful and kind in online chats.
‚Ä¢ Report anything that makes you uncomfortable.

Fun Tip: Create a checklist of safe internet habits and follow it every day.

lessons.title: What is Coding?
lessons.content:
Coding, also called programming, is giving instructions to a computer to make it perform tasks.

Why Coding is Important:
‚Ä¢ Helps computers understand what you want them to do.
‚Ä¢ Lets you create games, apps, and websites.
‚Ä¢ Improves problem-solving and logical thinking skills.

How it Works:
‚Ä¢ You write code in a programming language.
‚Ä¢ The computer reads the instructions and executes them.

Fun Fact: Even video games are built using coding!

lessons.title: Programming Languages for Kids
lessons.content:
A programming language is a special way of communicating with a computer. Just like we speak English or Yoruba to people, we use programming languages to talk to computers and tell them what to do.

Why Do We Need Programming Languages?
Computers don‚Äôt understand human language. They only understand instructions written in code. A programming language helps us write those instructions in a way computers can understand and follow easily.

Popular Programming Languages for Kids:
üé® Scratch: Scratch uses colorful blocks that snap together like puzzle pieces. It‚Äôs great for beginners who want to create animations, games, and stories without typing real code.

üêç Python: Python is a simple and powerful text-based programming language. It‚Äôs used to build websites, games, robots, and artificial intelligence. Its words look like plain English, so it‚Äôs easy to read and learn.

üåê HTML & CSS: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is used to build web pages, and CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to decorate them with colors, fonts, and layouts. Together, they make the internet beautiful!

‚ö° JavaScript: This language makes web pages come alive! It adds movement, buttons, games, and interactivity to websites. Most websites use JavaScript.

üß± Blockly: Similar to Scratch, Blockly uses drag-and-drop code blocks. It helps children learn logic before switching to text-based coding.

Other Fun Languages for Kids:
‚Ä¢ Logo: Famous for drawing shapes with a turtle on the screen.
‚Ä¢ Swift Playgrounds: Teaches Apple app coding through games.
‚Ä¢ Kodu: Lets kids create 3D games visually.

Tips for Young Coders:
‚úÖ Start with block-based tools like Scratch or Blockly.
‚úÖ Move on to text-based coding (like Python) when ready.
‚úÖ Practice with mini-projects like games or animations.
‚úÖ Learn from online tutorials and videos.
‚úÖ Remember: making mistakes (called debugging) is how programmers grow!

Fun Fact:
Did you know? The word ‚ÄúPython‚Äù didn‚Äôt come from the snake ‚Äî it came from a British comedy show called Monty Python‚Äôs Flying Circus!

lessons.title: Block Coding with Scratch
lessons.content:
Block coding is a fun and easy way to learn programming. Instead of typing words, you use colorful blocks that fit together like puzzle pieces to tell the computer what to do.

Why is it Called Block Coding?
Each block represents a command ‚Äî for example, move 10 steps or say Hello! You can join these blocks together to create programs. This helps kids understand the logic of coding without worrying about spelling or typing errors.

What is Scratch?
Scratch is the most popular block coding platform made by MIT for kids. It allows you to create games, stories, and animations just by dragging and dropping blocks.

How to Get Started with Scratch:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Visit scratch.mit.edu or download the offline Scratch app.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Choose a sprite (a character like a cat, ball, or person).
3Ô∏è‚É£ Drag blocks from the toolbox to the coding area.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Snap them together to make your sprite move, speak, or react.

Main Block Categories in Scratch:
üîπ Motion: Move or turn the sprite.
üîπ Looks: Make the sprite talk or change color.
üîπ Sound: Play music or sound effects.
üîπ Events: Start your program when you click a flag or press a key.
üîπ Control: Repeat actions or wait for a few seconds.
üîπ Sensing: Detect when sprites touch or the mouse moves.
üîπ Operators: Do math and comparisons.
üîπ Variables: Store information (like score or time).

Advantages of Block Coding:
‚úÖ Easy to understand for young learners.
‚úÖ No typing errors or confusing symbols.
‚úÖ Encourages creativity and problem-solving.
‚úÖ Builds confidence before learning real code.

Fun Project Ideas:
üéÆ Create a game where a cat catches a flying ball.
üé¨ Animate a story with characters talking.
üé® Design an interactive greeting card for a friend.
üéµ Make a musical project where sprites dance to sound.

From Blocks to Text:
Once you master Scratch, you can move to Python or JavaScript to write real code. The skills you learn in Scratch will make text-based coding much easier.

Fun Fact:
The famous Scratch Cat you see in the app is called the Sprite Mascot, and it has been helping millions of kids learn to code around the world!

lessons.title: Introduction to Text-Based Coding
lessons.content:
Text-based coding means giving instructions to a computer by typing words, numbers, and symbols in a programming language. It is how programmers make computers, websites, and robots work.

What is Coding?
Coding is the process of writing step-by-step instructions that a computer can follow to perform tasks. These instructions are called programs or scripts.

When you write code, you are actually teaching the computer what to do ‚Äî because computers cannot think for themselves. They only do what you tell them through code.

What is Text-Based Coding?
Text-based coding uses typed words and characters instead of blocks or icons. You write your code directly using letters, numbers, and special symbols.

Examples of popular text-based programming languages are:
‚Ä¢ Python ‚Äì a simple and beginner-friendly language used for games, websites, and apps.
‚Ä¢ HTML ‚Äì used for creating web pages and websites.
‚Ä¢ JavaScript ‚Äì adds interactivity and animations to web pages.
‚Ä¢ Scratch (Text Mode) ‚Äì advanced learners can type Scratch code instead of using blocks.

Examples of Simple Codes:
‚úÖ Python: print("Hello, World!") ‚Äì This shows a message on the screen.
‚úÖ HTML: <h1>My First Web Page</h1> ‚Äì This creates a big heading on a webpage.
‚úÖ JavaScript: alert('Welcome to Coding!'); ‚Äì This pops up a message box on the screen.

Why Learn Text-Based Coding?
1Ô∏è‚É£ It helps you think logically and solve problems.
2Ô∏è‚É£ You can create apps, websites, and games.
3Ô∏è‚É£ You gain real-world computer skills useful in many jobs.
4Ô∏è‚É£ You understand how technology around you works.

Tips for Beginners:
‚Ä¢ Start with simple commands and short programs.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt be afraid to make mistakes ‚Äî that‚Äôs how you learn!
‚Ä¢ Always read error messages carefully; they help you find what went wrong.
‚Ä¢ Practice daily ‚Äî the more you code, the better you get.
‚Ä¢ Watch coding videos or join a coding club to learn faster.

Fun Fact:
Every mobile app, website, and video game you use was created using text-based coding. Even robots and smart devices obey lines of code written by programmers!



Remember: Learning to code means learning how to think like a computer scientist. You‚Äôre not just using technology ‚Äî you‚Äôre creating it!

lessons.title: Simple Coding Projects for Kids
lessons.content:
Practicing coding by creating projects helps you understand programming better.

Project Ideas:
‚Ä¢ Interactive Story: Make characters move, talk, or change backgrounds.
‚Ä¢ Simple Game: Create a game with scoring, levels, and sounds.
‚Ä¢ Calculator: Build a program that adds, subtracts, multiplies, or divides.
‚Ä¢ Animation: Make characters dance, move, or react to clicks.

Tips:
‚Ä¢ Start small and add features gradually.
‚Ä¢ Test often to see if your program works.
‚Ä¢ Share your projects with friends or teachers for feedback.
